  • View page source

inconsistency-introduction-1ïƒ

See also

inconsistency-introduction-2 | inconsistency-introduction-3

Definitionïƒ

inconsistency-introduction-1 is the inference-rule:

\[\left( P, \neg \left(P\right) \right) \vdash Inc\left(\mathcal{T}\right)\]

In straightforward language, if we prove a proposition and its negation, it follows that the theory is inconsistent.

Quotesïƒ

Python implementationïƒ

The simplest way to use this inference-rule is to access it via the inference_rules (abridged i ) property of the theory-elaboration-sequence:

u = pu.create_universe()
t = u.t()
...
# some theory elaboration code
...
t.i.inconsistency_introduction_1.infer_statement(p = ...)

If the inference-rule was not yet declared in the universe-of-discourse , it will be automatically declared. If the inference-rule was not yet included in the theory-elaboration-sequence , it will be automatically included.

This calls the following method:

class core.InconsistencyIntroduction1Inclusion(t, echo=None, proof=None)
infer_statement(p=None, not_p=None, inconsistent_theory=None, nameset=None, ref=None, paragraph_header=None, subtitle=None, echo=None)

Apply the inconsistency-introduction inference-rule and return the inferred-statement.

Parameters:

  • p â€“ (mandatory) .

  • not_p â€“ (mandatory) .

  • inconsistent_theory â€“ (conditional) .

Returns:

An inferred-statement proving p in the current theory.

Python sample usageïƒ

Source code

 1import punctilious as pu
 2
 3# Create a universe-of-discourse with basic objects for the sake of this example.
 4u = pu.UniverseOfDiscourse(echo=True)
 5o1 = u.o.declare()
 6o2 = u.o.declare()
 7r1 = u.r.declare(2, signal_proposition=True)
 8t1 = u.t(echo=True)
 9axiom = u.declare_axiom(natural_language='Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes')
10
11# Elaborate a dummy theory with inconsistent propositions
12theory_axiom = t1.include_axiom(axiom)
13p = t1.i.axiom_interpretation.infer_statement(theory_axiom, r1(o1, o2))
14not_p = t1.i.axiom_interpretation.infer_statement(theory_axiom, u.r.lnot(r1(o1, o2)))
15t1.stabilize()
16
17# Use a distinct theory T2 to demonstrate the inconsistency of T1
18# because T1 could not prove its own inconsistency because it is inconsistent!
19t2 = u.t()
20
21# And finally, use the inconsistency-introduction-1 inference-rule:
22proposition_of_interest = t2.i.inconsistency_introduction_1.infer_statement(p=p, not_p=not_p,
23    inconsistent_theory=t1, subtitle='The proposition of interest')

Plaintext output

Let "U30" be a universe-of-discourse.

Let "T1" be a theory-elaboration-sequence in U30.

Axiom (T1.A1): Let axiom A1 "Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes" be included (postulated) in T1.

Inference rule (axiom-interpretation): Let inference-rule axiom-interpretation defined as "A |- P" be included and considered valid in T1.

Proposition (T1.P1): r1(o1, o2). Proof: "Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes" is postulated by axiom (A1). r1(o1, o2) is a valid formula statement interpreted from that axiom.Therefore, by the axiom-interpretation inference rule: A |- P, it follows that r1(o1, o2). QED

Warning (warning1): By design, punctilious assures the syntactical correctness of theories, but does not perform any semantic verification. Therefore, the usage of inference-rules that interpret natural content (i.e. axiom-interpretation and definition-interpretation) is critically dependent on the correctness of the content translation performed by the theory author, from axiom or definition natural language, to formulae.

Proposition (T1.P2): not(r1(o1, o2)). Proof: "Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes" is postulated by axiom (A1). not(r1(o1, o2)) is a valid formula statement interpreted from that axiom.Therefore, by the axiom-interpretation inference rule: A |- P, it follows that not(r1(o1, o2)). QED

Inference rule (inconsistency-introduction-1): Let inference-rule inconsistency-introduction-1 defined as "(P, not(P)) |- (T)" be included and considered valid in T2.

Proposition (T2.P3) - The proposition of interest: Inc(T1). Proof: Let P := r1(o1, o2), which follows from prop. (P1). Let not(P) := not(r1(o1, o2)), which follows from prop. (P2). Therefore, by the inconsistency-introduction-1 inference rule: (P, not(P)) |- (T), it follows that Inc(T1). QED
